1.text: Lo, all—hath mine eye seen, Heard hath mine ear, and it attendeth to it.

2.text: According to your knowledge I have known—also I. I am not fallen more than you.

3.text: Yet I for the Mighty One do speak, And to argue for God I delight.

4.text: And yet, ye are forgers of falsehood, Physicians of nought—all of you,

5.text: O that ye would keep perfectly silent, And it would be to you for wisdom.

6.text: Hear, I pray you, my argument, And to the pleadings of my lips attend,

7.text: For God do ye speak perverseness? And for Him do ye speak deceit?

8.text: His face do ye accept, if for God ye strive?

9.text: Is it good that He doth search you, If, as one mocketh at a man, ye mock at Him?

10.text: He doth surely reprove you, if in secret ye accept faces.

11.text: Doth not His excellency terrify you? And His dread fall upon you?

12.text: Your remembrances are similes of ashes, For high places of clay your heights.

13.text: Keep silent from me, and I speak, And pass over me doth what?

14.text: Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth? And my soul put in my hand?

15.text: Lo, He doth slay me—I wait not! Only, my ways unto His face I argue.

16.text: Also—He is to me for salvation, For the profane cometh not before Him.

17.text: Hear ye diligently my word, And my declaration with your ears.

18.text: Lo, I pray you, I have set in order the cause, I have known that I am righteous.

19.text: Who is he that doth strive with me? For now I keep silent and gasp.

20.text: Only two things, O God, do with me: Then from Thy face I am not hidden.

21.text: Thy hand put far off from me, And Thy terror let not terrify me.

22.text: And call Thou, and I—I answer, Or—I speak, and answer Thou me.

23.text: How many iniquities and sins have I? My transgression and my sin let me know.

24.text: Why dost Thou hide Thy face? And reckonest me for an enemy to Thee?

25.text: A leaf driven away dost Thou terrify? And the dry stubble dost Thou pursue?

26.text: For Thou writest against me bitter things, And causest me to possess iniquities of my youth:

27.text: And puttest in the stocks my feet, And observest all my paths, On the roots of my feet Thou settest a print,

28.text: And he, as a rotten thing, weareth away, As a garment hath a moth consumed him.
